Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cell Salvage in Obstetrics

Background: Cell salvage in obstetrics remains controversial. This study aimed to assess amniotic fluid (AF), heparin, and fetal red cell contamination in washed filtered salvaged maternal blood, comparing the use of one versus two suction devices.

Methods: In this exploratory trial, 34 patients undergoing elective Caesarean section at the Royal Cornwall Hospital were alternately assigned to Group 1 (n=17, one suction) or Group 2 (n=17, two suctions) over a 4-month period. The primary outcome was the reduction of AF, heparin, and fetal red cells post-filtration. Randomisation was alternate assignment, and no blinding was implemented.

Results: Post-filtration, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), squames cells, and heparin were significantly reduced (P<0.001) in both groups. Mean AFP levels were 2.58 IU/ml in Group 1 and 3.53 IU/ml in Group 2. Squames cells were nearly eliminated, with only two cases showing residual cells. Fetal red blood cells persisted, ranging from 0.13% to 4.35%. Group 1 had higher haemoglobin and haematocrit levels than Group 2, with lower white blood cell, AFP, and fetal red cell counts. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The study supports the use of cell salvage with a leucodepletion filter in obstetrics, showing minimal AF contamination. Further research is needed to confirm these findings.

Funding: Supported by an educational grant from Pall Medical.
